reviewText:
Space Channel 5: Part 2 is the greatest rhythm game ever made.

Whereas literally every other rhythm game ever is merely about watching symbols and icons falling into their place, perfectly playable with the music muted simply just by watching the screen, requiering no actual sense of rhythm, Space Channel 5: Part 2 features ABSOLUTELY NO VISUAL INDICATION of when you are supposed to press the buttons! Space bad guys bust a move in perfect synch to the (awsome, nigh-infinitely varied) background music, and you need to use the arrow keys or the D-Pad to bust those move right back at 'em! If you have no sense of rhythm, if you can't feel the beat of the music, if you can't use it to instantly determine when is the right moment to press buttons, you will fail, and fail hard. Simple as that.

The game, as far as video games have come as of yet, is the medium's ultimate example of merging a game's music in perfect synchronicity with the player's actions. Playing the game is essentially palying an interactive dance flick with occasional musical numbers. A Broadway production in which YOU are the star.

Did I mention that this game looks like whath the future would look like if the sixties never ended? Did I mention that this game ACTUALLY TELLS A STORY? WIth CONFLICT and stuff?

Oh, and did I mention that this game has MICHAEL JACKSON?

There is so much, oh so so so much more to be said about this game, but alas the Steam review section could simply never accomodate for it. Suffice it to say, to this day, there has yet to be a a rhythm game developed that is superior to Space Channel 5: Part 2.

reviewText: Sometimes there is beauty in simplicity. If you really break it down, Space Channel 5 isn't much more than a glorified version of Simon in a jetsons-esque retro future setting but in reality it is much more than that. It represents a lost era in gaming when music games were filled with crazy settings and ridiculous characters. Playing as a stylish news reporter that's saving lives one dance battle at a time is something that really could only happen in the dreamcast/ps2 era when budgets were less out of control. It's a game that is filled with a unique style and an inviting atmosphere focused on just having fun. Space Channel 5 may be a simple game, but there still isn't much out there quite like it.

reviewText:
This is my first review, so if my review is poor, my apologies.

Space Channel 5 is a rhythm game made by SEGA. I first heard about it through Project X Zone on the 3DS. I'm glad I did, I enjoyed this game quite a lot despite me not being too interested in rhythm games or SEGA games. I say all of this because it helps explain that I'm playing this game, not as an expert, but more of a novice or amateur.

A general rule of thumb for me is that gameplay is most important, and neither voice acting nor visuals usually matter. My visual preference is cartoony, not realism, and so I feel that I should leave it off to limit bias as much as I can (Although, isn't bias the whole point of a review?) This is how it works for me specifically. Sorry if you disagree with that.

For a rhythm game, I feel that the order of importance for the review should be gameplay, music, and finally plot.

Gameplay: The gameplay is basic and easy to follow. You hit the 6 designated buttons when prompted in alignment with the beat of the music. If you are good at both timing and memory, and enjoy them, I'd recommend this game. The game's first two stages will give you a lot of leeway to make mistakes to get yourself situated with the game. All stages have segments that enough misses will cause you to fail the level and you can start from either a checkpoint or from the beginning, it's up to you.

Music: I am no music connoisseur, but I really like the soundtrack. I think it's supposed to sound like pop, but I think that because Space Michael, a major character in the game, is voiced by Michael Jackson. It's really catchy, so I didn't have much trouble following the beat.

Plot: I won't give away spoilers, you can do it yourself by watching Youtube or similar video-sharing platforms if you wish. Going into a rhythm game or a Mario game for an interesting and deep story is like talking to a wall; You'll usually feel disappointment. The controls to the game are simple. The villians do their part and all you have to do is repeat what they did including the deliberate pauses. You have the up, down, left, right, and two other buttons for a total of 6 possible moves. If your timing is good and you can get 100% the level rewards you with a new costume.

This is where I cannot recommend the game. A few patches has worked to syncing the game to the keyboard/controller but there are several areas where you will know that you pushed the button correctly and it did not register at the right moment, the sequence starts a split second after the villians even though they had a longer starting pause, or your part of the song is off sync with the music because of what your side says compared to the villians. At this point, it becomes more memorization than anticipation. Since this is the main focus of the game, I cannot fully recommend the game.

Graphics wise, this is a port of a dreamcast game so you should not be expecting HD graphics. In fact, the original versions looked pretty much just like this. The fact that there is upscaling and V-sync is a bonus. One of the really interesting things is on some of the boss scenes the background moves in the same direction as the boss so you definitely know which move they did.

The music is a variety of upbeat songs some of which are from the original game. They do not stand out but are not overbearing. I am a HUGE fan of the Playstation 2 version of Space Channel 5: Part 2, but this port is absolutely riddled with bugs.

In just a few hours of playing it, I've encountered:

* A bug where it only played in Japanese. The game has a customization" file that you can run when you start the game--I have to load that every time I play the game and toggle English-->Japanese-->English to get it to load in English.

* The audio settings seem to determine which of my two monitors it loads on. What?!

* SEVERE input lag on controllers. This thing *hates* my Xbox controller. I have no idea why.

* I had a lot more luck using the keyboard
